tool.title: The tool
tool.what: The main goal is to help you to create text/box shadow animations. At any moment, you can retrieve your animation as a CSS keyframes to use it in your web project.
tool.generate: Under the hood, the tool creates the animation with
tool.ifSupported: if your browser supports it, or with an injected CSS keyframes string.

input.title: The input
input.what: There are 3 things you can edit:
input.text: 1. The text style: under 'styles' card, the displayed text and his container CSS properties, such as color, background, font-size, padding, border-radius.
input.textAnimation: 2. The text animation parameters: under 'animation' card, the animation duration.
input.animation: 3. The animation keyframes: under the displayed text area. You can add, remove, duplicate, reverse, and edit the field's [text/box]-shadow CSS declarations. See the next part to understand how Keyframes works.

keyframes.title: Keyframes
keyframes.what: The keyframes are the CSS at-rule used to define the styles an element will have at various times. The tool is focused on the text-shadow and box-shadow properties to create glitch-like effect.
keyframes.how: The keyframes are defined by a list of ranges.
keyframes.range: A range represents a set of combinable fields.
keyframes.field: A field is a set of text-shadow and/or box-shadow CSS properties that will be applied to the text at a specific time.
keyframes.multipleRanges: You can have multiple ranges in the keyframes. The tool will accumulate the fields of each range to create the final animation.
keyframes.visualize: Ranges length represents the number of values which can have the shadow property.
keyframes.exemple: One range with 2 fields, one at 0%, and the other at 50%. We have only one range, so one potential value per shadow property.
keyframes.exemple2: What happens if we duplicate this range and reverse his colors ?
keyframes.result2bis: We can see that ranges are combined. Because we have same fields with same offset in percent in the keyframes, the tool understands that he have to cumulate values.
keyframes.exemple3: What happens if we change the offset position of the second field to 75% in the duplicated range ?
keyframes.result3bis: As you can see, there is only one value for 50% and 75%. Firstly, the frame 50% in range 1 has exactly the same parameters as the frame 75% in range 2 so the tool will merge them. Secondly, there is another subtility to understand:
keyframes.introduceFill: Not in this case, it's time to introduce the 'fill' option.
keyframes.fill: The 'fill' option is a boolean which indicates if the field should be applied to all the frames of the field area until the next field or range's end.
keyframes.fillExemple: In the previous exemples, all fields had the 'fill' option disabled.
keyframes.fillExemple2: If you take a look at the last ranges image, you can see a gradient from purple to red. This is because the animation will do a transition from the first field to the second field, that is the normal CSS keyframes behavior.
keyframes.fillExemple3: Now we change the second field's color of the second range in yellow:
keyframes.fillExemple3result: Because there are two ranges, it should be there two values, right ?
keyframes.fillExemple3resultbis: Remember, ranges are combinable. So in our exemple, with every fields with 'fill' option disabled, only both first field's range are at exact same position, so we accumulate the values. But it's not the case of the second field's ranges. So we have two values at 50% (from range 1) and 75% (from range 2).
keyframes.fillExemple4: With the 'fill' option enabled in every fields:
keyframes.fillExemple4result: We haven't any gradient anymore. The animation will apply the fields to all frames until the next field or animation's end. Let's check the output:
keyframes.fillExemple4resultbis: Disable the 'fill' option can be powerfull to have smooth transitions between two fields or range's end, but enable it can be usefull if you plan to specify a lot of fields.
keyframes.fillDefault: The 'fill' option is enabled by default. Having a mix of enabled and disabled 'fill' option in multiple ranges can be tricky, you should know exactly what you are doing.
keyframes.mistakes: A common mistake is to think that the second range will 'add' a value to our property. But if in every ranges at this offset it's the only active frame, it will resolve as the first value of the property. This creates a bridge between the second and the first range. If this isn't the wanted behavior, you have to rethink the animation.

export.title: Export
export.what: The export feature allows you to retrieve your animation as a CSS keyframes to use it in your web project.
export.kind: There are 3 ways to export the animation:
export.css: Export the CSS code, gives you the keyframes at-rule and the text style class.
export.js: Export the JS code with the Animation() web API.
export.config: Export the configuration, it will interest you only if you want to add your creation into the built-in presets. If you want to apply your animation for built-in presets, you can open an issue 'Add preset: My Awesome Animation Name' with the configuration output on the github repository. I will treat it as soon as possible.

import.title: Import
import.what: The import feature allows you to import a CSS keyframes to use it in the tool.
import.why: You worked hard on a keyframes and you want to visualize and edit it in the tool ? This feature is for you.
import.css: You have to provide at least the preset name and the keyframe at-rule, optionnaly the text style.

presets.title: Presets
presets.what: The tool comes with built-in presets. They are prefixed by a star '*'. You can choose one of them in the editor. You can also save your current settings as a custom preset.
presets.autosave: The tool will automatically save your custom presets in your browser's local storage.
presets.noSaveOnBuiltins: You can't save built-in presets. If you want to modify them, you have to create a custom preset from the wanted built-in.
presets.presetOfPreset: You can also create a custom preset from another custom preset.

field.title: Field
field.fillAllFramesDescription: If enabled, the shadow will be applied to all frames until the next field or animation's end. If disabled, the shadow will be applied to the current frame offset only.

rules.title: Import rules
rules.class: The text style must be a valid CSS rule with any selector.
rules.keyframes: The keyframe must be a valid CSS keyframes at-rule with any name.
rules.autoPrefixes: Vendor prefixes are supported (you don't need to remove them).
rules.onlyConfigClass: Only declarations handled by the tool are used.
rules.textDeclarations: Text style: color, background, font-size, padding, border-radius.
rules.otherIgnored: Other declarations are ignored (you don't need to remove them).

shortcuts.rightClickUp: Right-click up: cut a field at the mouse position.
shortcuts.rightClickDrag: Right-click drag: choose an offset to cut.
